questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening weakness in his right arm. His symptoms started 5 days ago when he was powerlifting and felt an intense shooting pain in his right elbow that radiated to his shoulder. The pain improved with ice packs, over-the-counter ibuprofen, and rest. He has weakness in his right arm and trouble lifting everyday objects, such as eating utensils. He is eager to return to lifting and is concerned about his ability to participate in sports. Four years ago, he fell off his bike during a triathlon and injured his right shoulder and neck; he finished the race and the pain resolved with ibuprofen. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (194 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the right arm shows no abnormalities. Active range of motion of the right arm is normal at the shoulder, elbow, and wrist joints. Muscle strength is 3/5 on flexion of the right elbow and on forearm supination but normal elsewhere. Sensation is intact. When the right bicep is squeezed with the elbow flexed, the forearm remains still. Examination of the left arm shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the right elbow shows no abnormalities. MRI confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and follow-up in three weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splinting is commonly used in patients with soft tissue (muscular, ligament) injuries and fractures to immobilize and protect the injured area, while promoting healing. Splinting would not be appropriate in patients with a distal biceps tendon rupture.

B) CORRECT:

Surgical repair is recommended for distal biceps tendon rupture, especially in patients who are younger, active and/or who require rapid restoration of elbow functionality (e.g., athletes, manual laborers). Early intervention is crucial and should be carried out as soon as possible to avoid complications such as contracture (due to soft tissue fibrosis), nerve injury, and functional limitation, which may make it impossible to approximate and attach the separated ends.

Patients with a proximal biceps tendon rupture should receive nonoperative conservative management.

C) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies can be performed to assess for musculocutaneous nerve injury, which innervates the biceps brachii and can manifest with decreased flexion at the elbow. However, musculocutaneous nerve injury would typically manifest with a loss of sensation of the lateral aspect of the forearm. Moreover, musculocutaneous nerve injuries that affect the biceps brachii are typically proximal and commonly result from brachial plexus injuries.

D) INCORRECT:

Subacromial glucocorticoid injections can be considered in patients with proximal biceps tendinopathy that does not respond to conservative therapies (e.g., NSAIDs) to reduce inflammation and alleviate pain. In patients with distal biceps tendon rupture, glucocorticoids are often reserved for those with contraindications to first-line therapy or if first-line treatment has failed. In younger patients who require a rapid return of functionality, a different step in management is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up in three weeks are appropriate in patients with a proximal biceps tendon rupture or in those with a distal biceps tendon injury who do not require a rapid return of functionality (e.g., because of low physical demands) or are poor surgical candidates (i.e., older patients, multiple comorbidities). Patients treated with conservative management have an increased risk of weakness in supination, flexion, and hand grip.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of elbow pain and arm weakness after powerlifting and an abnormal biceps squeeze test, all of which strongly suggest a distal biceps tendon rupture.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the office with a 4-week history of right-sided shoulder pain. The patient works as a painter, which requires repetitive strenuous overhead arm movements. He mentions that the pain increases when he paints ceilings. Over-the-counter pain medications have provided minimal relief. Two months ago, he had a minor bicycle accident after which he noticed some bruises over his right arm and shoulder but felt fine otherwise. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the anterior aspect of his right shoulder. When the patient fully extends his right arm with palm facing up and flexes his shoulder forward against resistance, the pain is reproduced. No abnormal muscle displacement is noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic degenerative rotator cuff tears are commonly caused by repetitive overhead activity (e.g., painting) and are often preceded by rotator cuff tendinopathy, which manifests with a gradual onset of shoulder pain that worsens with strenuous overhead arm movements. However, rotator cuff tears manifest with loss of strength and a negative Speed test. In patients with a rotator cuff tear, other tests (e.g., drop arm test, empty can test, lift-off test, belly press test, and infraspinatus test) may be positive.

B) INCORRECT:

An acromioclavicular joint separation is commonly caused by a fall on an adducted arm (e.g., while cycling) and can manifest with local pain and bruising. Individuals with acromioclavicular joint separation typically present with a limited range of motion of the shoulder joint. A cross-body adduction test, in which the patient elevates their arm to 90° and actively adducts it across their body, rather than a Speed test would be positive.

C) CORRECT:

Biceps tendinopathy (BT) is commonly caused by repetitive motions such as pulling or lifting and is associated with occupations that involve strenuous overhead activities (e.g., painting). BT typically manifests with the gradual onset of anterior shoulder pain that worsens with overhead reaching, tenderness over the bicipital groove, and positive provocation tests (e.g., Speed test, Yergason test). Diagnosis is primarily clinical.

Management of BT is conservative (e.g., physical therapy, ice packs, avoidance of overhead arm movements, analgesics). Osteopathic manipulative treatment includes identifying and eliminating any restrictions in the glenohumeral area and the use of myofascial release. Subacromial glucocorticoid injections are indicated for patients with BT that does not improve with conservative treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Glenohumeral joint instability is a complication of shoulder dislocation, which is commonly caused by trauma (e.g., falling from a bicycle and landing on an outstretched arm) and can manifest with severe shoulder pain and bruising. However, individuals with shoulder dislocation typically present with an empty glenoid fossa and the inability to move the shoulder, neither of which is seen in this patient. Additionally, joint instability can manifest as repeat dislocations, a feeling of the shoulder slipping in and out of the joint, and pain. Shoulder instability is evaluated by the drawer tests of the shoulder, not the Speed test.

E) INCORRECT:

Rotator cuff tendinopathies (e.g., supraspinatus tendinopathy) can be caused by repetitive overhead activities (e.g., painting) and manifest with a gradual onset of shoulder pain that worsens with overhead arm movements. Individuals with supraspinatus tendinopathy typically present with subacromial tenderness, referred pain in the deltoid area with overhead activities, and a restricted range of motion between 60–120° (painful arc), none of which is seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Proximal biceps tendon ruptures are commonly preceded by degenerative tendinopathy, which can cause anterior shoulder pain that worsens with overhead reaching (e.g., painting), tenderness over the bicipital groove, and a positive Speed test. Biceps tendon ruptures are typically painless and manifest with distal displacement of the biceps belly (popeye sign), which is not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Pain in the bicipital groove resulting from full extension of the right arm with the palm facing up and the shoulder flexed forward against resistance indicates a positive Speed test, which (if performed as described here) is also known as the palm-up test. A variation of the Speed test involves abduction of the patient's arm with the elbow flexed at 90° and the forearm supinated followed by bending of the elbow against resistance.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man who is right-hand dominant reports experiencing acute-onset right anterior shoulder pain, accompanied by a snapping sensation, as he lifted a heavy object overhead 3 days ago. The pain radiated from his anterior shoulder to the side of his arm during the lifting activity. He continues to feel a persistent, dull aching pain in his shoulder that is making it difficult for him to sleep at night. A carpenter by trade, he is generally well, regularly lifts weights at the gym, and has previously experienced only generalized shoulder discomfort related to his work.
Examination reveals a slight contour deformity of the right upper arm (compared with the left) without associated erythema. The anterior shoulder is tender to palpation. The patient has full active range of motion at the shoulder and elbow, but pain is elicited with resisted forward flexion of the shoulder, resisted flexion of the elbow, and supination of the arm.
Despite the pain, muscular testing on the right side is intact and symmetric compared with the left side. Hawkins, Speed, and Yergason tests are positive.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Rupture of the proximal biceps tendon

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rupture of the proximal biceps tendon is a clinical diagnosis made after a thorough history and physical examination. A complete rupture of the proximal biceps tendon results in a noticeable contour deformity of the biceps muscle belly, commonly called a Popeye deformity. There can be related ecchymosis along the fascial plane of the muscle. Tenderness is evident over the bicipital groove and along the biceps muscle.

The biceps’ mechanism of action is supination of the hand, flexion of the elbow, and forward flexion of the shoulder. Therefore, during these resisted motions on physical examination, patients with a biceps rupture have pain over the bicipital groove. A positive Speed test (pain with resisted downward force with the shoulder in 90 degrees of forward flexion and the arm supinated) and a positive Yergason test (pain with resisted supination of the forearm with the elbow flexed to 90 degrees) are specific for biceps tendon pathology.

This patient has several risk factors for biceps tendon rupture: his age (45–60), sex, and history of repetitive overhead activity, particularly with heavy objects. Other risk factors include nicotine use and any history of glucocorticoid injections in the shoulder.

Key learning point: Middle-aged patients with a history or symptoms of shoulder impingement are at increased risk for tendon rupture of the biceps, specifically the long head.

B) INCORRECT:

Supraspinatus tendinitis manifests with pain and weakness during the first 15 degrees of abduction of the shoulder. It has no effect on flexion of the elbow or supination.

C) INCORRECT:

Subacromial bursitis manifests with generalized lateral shoulder pain, palpable tenderness over the bursa, and a painful arc during abduction of the shoulder. It is not associated with contour deformity.

D) INCORRECT:

Acromioclavicular (AC) joint separation is diagnosed with palpable tenderness over the AC joint and pain elicited during cross-arm adduction with the shoulder at 90 degrees of flexion. Generally, there has also been a specific traumatic mechanism of injury, such as a sporting injury, a direct fall on the shoulder, or a fall on an outstretched hand.

E) INCORRECT:

Similar to a biceps tendon rupture, rotator cuff impingement yields a positive Hawkins sign (pain when internal rotation is applied to the arm with both the shoulder and elbow flexed to 90 degrees) and is associated with repetitive overhead activity. Impingement can also increase the risk for a future biceps tendon rupture related to the induced inflammation and fraying of the tendon. However, impingement does not cause pain with elbow flexion or supination and is not associated with a contour deformity of the shoulder.

questions.text:
A healthy 36-year-old man presents 2 days after injuring his right arm. He was helping a friend move and reports that while lifting a heavy box, he experienced a severe tearing pain at the right elbow, causing him to drop the box. Since the injury, he has been able to move the arm at the elbow but has had pain and diminished strength.
On examination, there is substantial bruising and a palpable defect at the antecubital fossa of the affected arm. When the patient is asked to flex his elbow, there is a palpable fullness in the proximal part of the medial upper arm, which is not present on the left side. The patient has pain and weakness with resisted flexion and supination. The rest of the neurovascular examination of his arm is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Apply a compression wrap until the bruising has resolved
Provide a sling, recommend rest and ice, and reevaluate in 3 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), rest, ice, a sling, and a compression wrap are used as part of the postoperative course. Preoperatively, NSAIDs should be avoided (because they increase bleeding risk), prolonged use of a sling can increase stiffness of the joint, and compression wraps may worsen pain. Ice can be used as a temporizing measure, but the patient should still be referred for surgical repair.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), rest, ice, a sling, and a compression wrap are used as part of the postoperative course. Preoperatively, NSAIDs should be avoided (because they increase bleeding risk), prolonged use of a sling can increase stiffness of the joint, and compression wraps may worsen pain. Ice can be used as a temporizing measure, but the patient should still be referred for surgical repair.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonoperative management is appropriate for patients with partial tears of the distal biceps tendon. It is also typically most appropriate for patients who are older, frail, sedentary, or at high risk for surgical intervention because of multiple comorbidities. These patients often do not require maximal elbow flexion and supination strength or endurance.

Patients who elect nonoperative management should be advised that the contour difference on the affected side will persist, and they may lose about half of their supination strength and endurance, some flexion strength, and most of their flexion endurance.

D) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), rest, ice, a sling, and a compression wrap are used as part of the postoperative course. Preoperatively, NSAIDs should be avoided (because they increase bleeding risk), prolonged use of a sling can increase stiffness of the joint, and compression wraps may worsen pain. Ice can be used as a temporizing measure, but the patient should still be referred for surgical repair.

E) CORRECT:

The findings of a palpable defect at the antecubital fossa, ecchymosis at the medial aspect of the elbow, palpable fullness in the proximal part of the medial upper arm with elbow flexion, and pain and weakness with flexion and supination of the elbow against resistance indicate a possible complete distal biceps tendon tear. This often occurs as a result of acute flexion load on the biceps muscle and can occur bilaterally.

Surgical repair is often indicated for patients with complete distal biceps tendon rupture. Tears older than 6 weeks can be surgically challenging; once 12 weeks have passed, tissue retraction and muscle atrophy preclude reattachment of the tendon to bone.

Nonoperative management is appropriate for patients with partial tears of the distal biceps tendon. It is also typically most appropriate for patients who are older, frail, sedentary, or at high risk for surgical intervention because of multiple comorbidities. These patients often do not require maximal elbow flexion and supination strength or endurance.

Patients who elect nonoperative management should be advised that the contour difference on the affected side will persist, and they may lose about half of their supination strength and endurance, some flexion strength, and most of their flexion endurance. Of note, the proximal tendon of the long head of the biceps runs through the shoulder at the rotator cuff, adjacent to the supraspinatus tendon. It is also prone to rupture, either from an acute load demand or as a result of chronic rotator cuff disease. Indications for operative and nonoperative intervention are similar, and young, otherwise healthy patients have the best chance of a positive surgical outcome.

In a young, healthy patient, surgical repair is the recommended treatment, given the risk of marked weakness with nonoperative management.

Physical therapy, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), rest, ice, a sling, and a compression wrap are used as part of the postoperative course. Preoperatively, NSAIDs should be avoided (because they increase bleeding risk), prolonged use of a sling can increase stiffness of the joint, and compression wraps may worsen pain. Ice can be used as a temporizing measure, but the patient should still be referred for surgical repair.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a complete distal biceps tendon rupture in an otherwise healthy and active patient is surgical repair.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man who is a mechanic presents with right arm pain after attempting to prevent a heavy engine from falling. He describes a sudden popping sensation followed by immediate pain. Examination shows ecchymosis in the antecubital fossa and visible deformity of the upper arm contour. The patient has marked difficulty with elbow flexion and forearm supination against resistance. What finding most reliably differentiates this injury from a proximal biceps tendon rupture?

choices.text: Visible deformity of the upper arm contour

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Visible deformity of the upper arm contour occurs in both proximal and distal biceps tendon ruptures, though the direction of muscle displacement differs between the two locations.

B) INCORRECT:

A sudden popping sensation can occur with both proximal and distal biceps tendon ruptures when the tendon detaches from bone, making this finding nondiscriminatory.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Marked weakness with forearm supination is the most reliable distinguishing feature of distal biceps tendon rupture. Proximal ruptures typically have no significant loss of function due to compensation by the intact short head of the biceps and coracobrachialis muscle, while distal ruptures cause significant limitation of both flexion and supination at the elbow joint.

D) INCORRECT:

Heavy lifting mechanisms can precipitate both proximal and distal biceps tendon ruptures, particularly when degenerative tendons are subjected to acute overloading or trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute upper arm pain occurs in both proximal and distal biceps tendon ruptures and is not a distinguishing feature between the two injury locations.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute right arm pain after lifting a heavy box. Vital signs are normal. Examination shows a bulge in the mid-biceps region, weakness with supination, and preserved elbow flexion strength. Distal neurovascular status is intact. X-ray of the shoulder, humerus, and elbow is normal. In addition to providing analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate management approach?

choices.text: Apply an arm sling and arrange outpatient orthopedic follow-up
Arrange immediate orthopedic consultation in the ED
Apply a long-arm splint and arrange outpatient MRI of the shoulder
Obtain urgent MRI of the shoulder
Admit to hospital for pain control and surgical planning

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — The clinical presentation with a visible mid-biceps bulge (Popeye sign) and preserved elbow flexion strength is consistent with proximal biceps tendon rupture. Proximal ruptures typically cause no significant loss of function since the short head remains intact and the brachialis muscle compensates. Initial management is conservative with a sling for comfort and outpatient orthopedic referral. Proximal biceps tendon rupture is most commonly managed conservatively, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory pain and/or higher physical demands.

B) INCORRECT:

While distal biceps tendon ruptures require urgent orthopedic involvement, this patient has a proximal rupture. Proximal ruptures rarely compromise function or require acute repair. Same-day consultation is unnecessary when the diagnosis is clear and the patient is stable.

C) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis is primarily clinical in biceps tendon rupture. MRI is indicated for chronic injury or unclear diagnosis but is not needed when clinical findings are classic, as in this case. Additionally, long-arm splints are not typically used for proximal biceps tendon ruptures.

D) INCORRECT:

While MRI may be used to confirm atypical or partial tears, it is not required for classic proximal ruptures and does not need to be obtained during the initial presentation to the emergency department.

E) INCORRECT:

Admission is not indicated for isolated proximal biceps ruptures. Pain is usually well-controlled with oral agents, and evaluation for surgery can be done in an outpatient setting.
